name: homologue
content:
Add to word list
Add to word list
formal something that has a similar position, structure, value, or purpose to something else: Chronic fatigue syndrome has had its homologues for many years, including such poorly described disease states as neurasthenia. I was reminded of the many similarities with the American Civil War of 1861-65: not just the death toll, but the homologue of Oxford and Richmond, Virginia, as doomed capitals.
biology
  specialized something that has the same origin as something else but now has a different purpose or shape as a result of evolution (= gradual change over millions of years): Connections between visual and cerebellar regions are putative human homologues of connections in the macaque brain.
biology
  specialized a chromosome (= a rod-like structure in cells, containing the chemical patterns that control what an animal or plant is like) that contains similar information to another chromosome that it forms a pair with during meiosis (= a type of cell division) : A diploid cell contains two of each type of chromosome, one homologue from the mother and one homologue from the father.
